column1: Which team will win the NFLâ€™s Super Bowl in 2016?

column6: ['Sports']
column11: Sign up and enter your own forecast, if you're here for The Economist's World in 2016 Challenge! The 50th Super Bowl will be held on 7 February 2016 (The World in 2016) in Santa Clara, California. The participants are the Denver Broncos v. the Carolina Panthers.

column6: Manning is a sentimental favorite, and the Panthers have never played in a Super Bowl.
A team with an out of form quarterback cannot win.

My initial forecast 32-68 for Panthers was based on my prediction engine (http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.04302). I then checked how many times a team reaching the super bowl with regular season record 15-1 (i.e., Panthers) actually won the Lombardi trophy. This was 100% and hence I updated my prediction to 78% for Panthers.

I have no knowledge of NFL whatsoever. My prediction is based on the fact, that I don't really care about being right on this question, but at the same time it would be neat to get good results here - and only way to do that now is right choice with massive certainty. Carolina panthers seem to be predicted by majority people here, so I'm making it my choice...
Prediction Machine causes reconsideration.
This is a pure guess, I have no knowledge of American football

Test of Carolina's offensive speed vs. Bronco's defensive speed. Have to give edge to Carolina defense vs. Bronco's offense (sorry, Payton, but your arm strength is not what it was even a year or two ago).

Counter-intuitively I think this question is as important as, "Who will be the next president?", "What will happen with the U.S. in the next 12 months?", and "What is the psychology of the U.S. consumer (i.e. sentiment) right now?"
Too many variables to consider with two very good teams
Manning ultra-motivated and arm strength coming on, Wade Phillips defense vs. relatively inexperienced Panthers.

Updating following divisional games: Very little change in the % now that the teams are known, and still predicting NFC (as has been the case throughout). The forecast method, however, predicted the opposite matchup (NE-ARI). A couple of thoughts on how I'd try to improve this method next time: I would account for both offense and defense (yd/pass attempt gained and allowed) and look at the margin of difference. Based on the outcomes during these playoffs, that difference may be more telling than yds/pass attempt alone. We'll see next year!
Cam Newton is highly mobile; Manning isn't. This will trump Denver's defense

The Carolina Panthers have a superior quarterback (Cam Newton) vs Peyton Manning (The Broncos) Peyton has had many injuries throughout his career, and has only became the starting quarterback recently while only being second-string. Cam Newton is a well known quarterback and has a much better run game and can make split decisions. Peyton's performance however in the Patriots game and his ability to throw deep passes may prove effective, however Cam has had a better passing game than Peyton this year.
Cam Newton is a thug
Vegas gives Denver a ~32% chance, and that is skewed in favor of the Broncos because they're a more famous/public team so I adjust downwards.

While the Panthers may hold a slight edge in pure overall athletic talent, the Broncos hold the intangibles edge. Bronco will win the forced turnover and made field goals battles, and ultimately the game.
Denver's D will contain the Panthers enough to enable their O to score 30 and win
Broncos have a great kicker and hold the "intangible" advantage. They will win if they can win the turnover challenge.

I'm surprised this is still a coin flip. I see that each team is playing games with the injury report. Here's a question that I've been asking myself: What happens if Carolina runs at the Denver defensive ends?
totally reversed the numbers first time- love this app. I stand corrected. panthers with cam newton will not be defeated
After averaging predictions of top analysts I have decided that the Carolina Panthers have a 62% chance of winning the Super Bowl.
quarterback is everything in this league and Cam Newton is on fire

PredictWise has the Panthers up 67/32, so the betting markets favor Carolina. Both teams have great defense - but Carolina probably has the edge in offense, given the way Manning's been playing. (See https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/peyton-manning-had-the-worst-season-of-any-super-bowl-quarterback-ever/) That said, if Denver can shut down Cam Newton like they did Tom Brady, then maybe they can pull out a win & let Manning retire on top. Hopefully it's a clean game. These retired NFL players calling for intentionally hurting Newton aren't doing anything to improve the NFL's reputation.
Two great defenses, but turnover margin and red zone performance are in the panthers favor. Expecting a lot of ground play from both squads.
Manning will have to perform extremely well for his offense to succeed here, and I don't think he will
Denver has a better defense, but Carolina is an all-around better team.
Carolina too strong on both offense and defense. If Carolina sets the pace of the game early and pressures Manning....game over! Manning not mobile enough to be effective.
Just boringly going with 538's prediction: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2015-nfl-predictions/
Favored -5.5 points in vegas. Carolina covered ATS 72.2% in the regular season.
NFC is a 6 point favorite in Vegas and watching the Broncos closely & I think (against hope) they've met their match.
I have an algorithm I've created and has been performing really well. My forecast for the winner would suggest Broncos on the spread is the bet for sports bettors.

The head ref is Clete Blakeman, he has one of the worst records this year for not calling offense penalties against teams, among other inconsistent professional judgements to have been selected as the head ref in the game. Since the Broncos have had more penalties this year, I am forecasting the Broncos as a slight favorite.

As the game progresses Peyton Manning will make more and more mistakes. The only hope the Broncos have of winning this game is keeping Peyton off the field. The Panthers offense match up well with the Bronco's defense. Unfortunately, the Broncos will struggle against Carolina's top tier defense.
Defense wins championship games...normally. Thus, the number 1 defense (Broncos) will defeat the Nuer Six defense team.

Current vegas odds have the Panthers at 6 point favorites, however as BarstoolSports.com pointed out weeks ago, the Panthers success and vegas odds are wildly at odds with one another ( http://www.barstoolsports.com/chicago/the-super-bowl-point-spread-is-out-and-carolina-is-officially-the-most-disrespected-15-win-team-of-all-time/ ). As Vegas sets their lines prompting a 50/50 split aiming at their attempt to maximize their expected value, I believe it is skewed by the large proportion of the population that wants to bet on Peyton Manning and, more importantly, AGAINST the evil empire Carolina Panthers. That said, I would be comfortable betting on the Panthers pure ability to win the Super Bowl as 10+ point favorites, thus resulting in my 79% win prediction.
Vegas moneyline...

Madden Simulation perfectly predicted game last year. They're predicting Carolina over Broncos, 24-20. Microsoft Bing is also choosing Carolina to win with 64% probability. Microsoft Bing has had 63% accuracy rating throughout NFL season.

I haven't followed the NFL in recent years, so this is a gamble. I'll just go with the betting markets.

The odds of Cam Newton out-playing Peyton Manning are favorable, and, no matter how good the Broncos' defense is, the offense must be able to put points on the board. I predict Cam will be able to do this better than Peyton.

The Panthers have been so dominating during the playoffs, I don't see them lose.
Flipped to a slight edge for Denver. Peyton's most likely "last rodeo". Denver has the better defense. When in doubt, lean toward the better defense, and better story line.

Aggressive forecast in favor of the Panthers but I do not see any injuries or compelling reason that they will not win unless key players do not perform on game day. I will stay with my conviction but lower slightly as there is a possibility the Broncos will win given Peyton's, in particular, experience but Cam Newton and co. seem to thrive under pressure.
Panthers are better in all 3 phases, simply are the better team, although Denver with its defence could throw up a surprise
Reference to Nate Silver at http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2015-nfl-predictions/, rounding to nearest 10.

Prediction markets show 68% odds of Panthers winning. I pushed it out to 71% from speaking to a few knowledgable friends, the fact that the bookies have to hedge the larger amount of bets on higher payout bets.

a $240 bet on Carolina earns $100; a $100 bet on Denver earns $200. Assuming the bookies take even spreads on both spread that puts odd at 67.9% for a Carolina victory (32.1% for Denver). Psychological factors may make the underdog bet more enticing and interesting. After all who wants to put up $240 to make $100. That's not a fun bet. This pushed my spread a little wider.
Cam Newton is having an amazing season, Peyton is way past his prime A head-to-head analysis indicates Newton's higher level of athleticism, which could be a catalyst in the game
Broncos by a snoot. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zEYvuOt5P4
Both teams have great defenses. The dual threat of Cam Newton makes it more difficult for Denver to game plan.
Denver's defense, rated number one in the NFL, will get to Newt, the same way they got to Brady. While Manning doesn't have to body to move the ball, he does have the brain; he's still got the arm.

While I would love to see Payton win the super-bowl in his last year of his Hall of Fame career, life just doesn't throw us that many fairy-tales, and I don't think it will happen. Defense-shmeefense. The Panthers have too many offensive weapons. And Defense DOESN'T win championships, as earlier noted in a previous prediction. (though he did pick the Broncos)
Holy schnikes, the question is starting to skew. Must front run.

I wanted to give the Broncos a storng edge, because they have the better defence, but in the long term, defence is no more valuable than offence according to http://freakonomics.com/2012/01/20/does-defense-really-win-championships/. That said, the Broncos' pass rush, their experience in the Super Bowl (18 players have been there against 6 for the Panthers) and Manning's opponent's inexperience probably give a small advantage to the Broncos.

Black Swan theory + Peyton's last rodeo. Will not be graceful, pretty, or smooth, but they will win.
For my stock portfolio, go Panthers. Defense wins championship games. So, the best defensive team (Broncos) will defeat the sixth ranked defensive team (Panthers).

It seems highly likely that Panthers are a better team in a better form but football is said to be highly strategic and if so I can imagine that a quality of coach and, in particular, his ability to adjust game to different opponents/situations, can be deciding.

At the same time the oppossition quarterback is younger , moves with ease and pretty confident . I hope it will be a high scoring super ball .may the best team win !

There are too many good players on defense and with an aging Peyton Manning not being able to sling the ball like he used to, Carolina's defense will be too much to put enough points on the board to match Carolina. Despite Denver having a top ranked defense itself, they will get tired down by the second half from being on the field too much.
It's a good match, but the Panthers are favored slightly.

Panthers defense is extremely good against passing plays. Defensive line for panthers and broncos are both very good at putting pressure on the quarterback. Payton Manning is a veteran but Cam Newton is a great athlete that can also run the ball.

Carolina is too powerful this year, and Cam Newton is a monster. I like Peyton Manning (since he's no longer playing for Indianapolis, who stole the Colts from Baltimore--which I'll never forgive; I also think that his father might have been better if he had been on a good team), but Peyton's not what he used to be. Denver was lucky to beat the Patriots, and they'll need a miracle to win the Superbowl (IMHO). Though I like Denver and like to root for the underdog, I guess I'll have to root for Carolina now.

In the matchup between the Carolina Panthers (NFC) and the Denver Broncos (AFC) I believe the Panthers have a superior defense, a better QB, and have played better competition throughout the year. Although, I would not entirely rule out the possibility of a Broncos victory, the underwhelming performance of star QB Peyton Manning would lead me to believe he would need to perform well above his averages this year: 59.8% completion rate, 225 yards per game, and a TD/INT ratio of 9/17; moreover these are all career low numbers for the 39 year old QB. The panthers are also favored at -5.5 points, which leads me to believe bookmakers see a Panthers victory to be more likely.

Teams with the best defense (yards/game) in the league are 9-2 in the Super Bowl. Teams with the best offense (points/game) are 10-9 in the Super Bowl. Denver has the best defense in the league and Carolina has the best offense. Denver is most likely to win. Kicking and Screaming.

Going with the Carolina Panthers (NFC) over the Broncos (AFC). I don't think the Broncos have enough to slow down the juggernaut that is the Panthers' offense. However, given how well Denver played in beating New England - which I didn't think they'd do - I'll still give Denver a 40% chance.
Injuries in Broncos secondary give me pause. Newton's speed and mobility suggest he will not be Brady-ed by the pass rush

With his high-octane offense and high mobility, Cam Newton should fare well against the Broncos' defense. In addition, the Panthers should be able to pressure Manning early and often.

After watching Carolina slaughter Arizona, and Denver squeak past New England, I think the mostly likely winner is Carolina. Cam Newton is the best quarterback that I've ever seen play, and that goes back to the 50s. Passing is excellent -- behind excellent pass protection, for sure -- rushing is superb; the only thing he hasn't done is catch a pass. (Tom Brady and Shaun Hill are the only QBs to do so in modern times: Amendola to Brady, and Hill to Hill -- yes, he caught his own pass.) The Broncos defense was excellent, but the offense was only so-so.

My original forecast about the Patriots playing in Denver happened exactly the way I predicted. The defense manned up the Patriots and forced Brady to hold onto the ball longer for the pass rushers to get to him. Denver vs. and it looks like Carolina early on, man defense typically does not do well against the option offense. The reason is that the OLBs (Miller and Ware) must be able to crash down on the run or come down on Cam. Cam is just too big and fast to be successful on every play. Carolina wins it this year. I'll push it to 90% and won't go any further because I don't know the party habits of the players leading up to the Super Bowl.

Based on history, it seems that things should be about 50-50. However, we of course do need to take into account the fact that teams change their composition fairly frequently. Additionally, it seems that the Carolina Panthers have done a phenomenal job this season, and may be the team carrying the NFC to a Super Bowl win overall, although more data might be needed to substantiate this claim and determine whether they simply have faced opponents that were, on average, "easier" than an otherwise equivalent or similar team in the AFC.

I'm going with the FiveThirtyEight odds here. There are some deep thinkers with much more faith in the NFC, but I don't have much confidence in forecasts like "Team X isn't a real contender" or "Team Y should beat either of the teams left on the other side". Football is a high-variance sport, every team left in the playoffs is quite strong, and FiveThirtyEight's simulations seem far more advanced/predictively powerful than anything we can figure out.
Charlotte Panthers will win. Hungry, confident team.

The winner of the game between Seattle and Carolina will be the NFC winner. Den will beat Pitt. NE is the only team in the AFC that can beat the likely teams to come out of the NFC. For the AFC to win, NE has to emerge as the winner of that conference. New England has an 80% to beat Kansas City. If they do, they will win the AFC. If NE does loose, neither Denver or KC can beat either Seattle of Carolina. If NE wins the AFC and they will only do so if they are healthy, a healthy NE has an 80% chance to beat any NFC Team.
At this point the Panthers are the team to beat, and the Cardinals are second. Both are in the NFC

Desire wins over the experience in this super bowl.

First, let's group likely playoff teams into two groups: contenders (Arizona, Carolina, and New England) and pretenders (everyone else). There are four possible Super Bowl match ups: contender v. contender, NFC contender v. AFC pretender, AFC contender v. NFC pretender, and pretender v. pretender. Let's assume that a contender will always be favored against a pretender and that pretender-pretender and contender-contender match-ups would be even odds. The NFC's superior championship odds are mainly a function of the fact that it is much more likely that a NFC contender matches up against an AFC pretender. Because the Patriots are the only AFC contender, it is much more likely they would be upset than having both Carolina and Arizona not advance to the Super Bowl. I assumed that contenders would be 55% favorites in match-ups against pretenders but, even dropping that percentage to 51%, the NFC would still be a 55% favorite.

Any Given Sunday holds true throughout the playoffs for 4 weeks of games - that said current Vegas odds for the Patriots are 3/1 (AFC) and for Cardinals and Panthers both at 11/2 (both NFC) and for Denver Broncos 10/1 (AFC) and if you go down the list of increasing odds the cumulative odds for the AFC vs NFC is fairly even though the AFC is more of a longshot than the NFC in the top current 16 favored teams. But the cumulative odds equation is too difficult and time consuming for me to attempt currently and I am using a bias and "guessing" that it is not much more than a flip of a coin if you compound all of the probabilities and then weight subjectively for current power rankings and the number of variables that can change are just too many even in this short window of time (for instance Tom Brady could get injured or Cam Newton that would vastly affect the probabilistic outcomes). I also don't aggregate to 100% because while it is clearly less than 1% chance there is still the remotest of possibilities that the Super Bowl is not played due to a black swan event and even though the probability of such an event of such magnitude happening is probabily less than even 1/10th of a percent, I did want to give voice to the likelihood of neither winning is >0.

Panthers 84% because I really don't think any team in the NFC will beat them in the playoffs. I think the only team in the AFC that can beat them is the Patriots if Gronk, Amendola and Edelman (miracously) return healthy. However, I don't think they will make it pass the Broncos and the Broncos do not have any decisive advantage over the Panthers. The Panthers have to play three games to win it all (66%/game), if healthy Patriots make it (33%), but I think Broncos will make it so I cut their percentage in half and gave it to the Panthers.

Patriots have too many injuries; Brock Ostweiler has given new energy to Broncos, so team can feel secure if Manning cannot play, and still have time to address lack of consistency in the offense. Seahawks will still be a strong challenge but their QB strength will wane as season continues and injuries begin to take a toll.

First I found the record of the AFC and NFC, then I added together the records of the top teams in each division. Then, I added the AFC record and 1/4 of the division leaders records (because they count as 1/4 of the division), and the NFC record and 1/4 of their division leaders records, and then I divided that number by the total amount of wins.
